profileText: A Representative from New Hampshire; born in Greenland, Rockingham County, N.H., March 31, 1781; attended the common schools; learned the carpenter's trade; during the War of 1812 recruited a company for the Eleventh Regiment of United States Infantry and served as its captain; promoted to the rank of major; after the war resided in Coos County, N.H., where he held several local offices; elected as a Jacksonian to the Twenty-first and Twenty-second Congresses (March 4, 1829-March 3, 1833); died in Lancaster, Coos County, N.H., April 3, 1853; interment in the Old Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: In Weeks family papers, 1669-1908. 1,143 items and 7 volumes.
1804-1849, approximately 250 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers of John Wingate Weeks contain correspondence, together with a few documents, invitations, and printed circulars, relating chiefly to Weeks's routine affairs as an army captain in the War of 1812, as sheriff of Coos County, N.H., and as a member of Congress. .

researchRecord.name: 1814, amount unknown.
researchRecord.description: The collection includes letters from Major John Wingate Weeks which were later transcribed. The letters document military actions include Camp Buffalo and Camp Queenstown, New York State in 1814.
